steps: Update all drivers using Windows Update or manufacturer's website.
Run System File Checker using command: sfc /scannow.
Use Windows Memory Diagnostic to check for RAM issues.
Perform a clean boot to identify problematic background programs.
problems.technical_details: Occurs when a critical system process fails due to corrupted files, faulty drivers, or memory issues.

steps: Update all drivers in Device Manager.
Run Windows Memory Diagnostic to check for RAM issues.
Run disk check using command: chkdsk /f /r.
Uninstall any recent Windows updates that might have caused the issue.
problems.technical_details: Caused by faulty drivers or memory corruption leading to invalid memory access.

steps: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic to check for RAM issues.
Update all device drivers.
Check the hard drive for issues using chkdsk /f /r.
Uninstall recently added software that could be causing conflicts.
problems.technical_details: Occurs when the system requests data that is not in memory, often due to hardware or driver problems.

steps: Ensure Windows is up-to-date by checking Windows Update.
Update all drivers using Device Manager.
Run System File Checker (sfc /scannow) to check for corrupt files.
Scan for malware using Windows Defender or another antivirus program.
problems.technical_details: Happens due to outdated drivers, software conflicts, or malware infections.

steps: Update graphics drivers from NVIDIA, AMD, or Intel websites.
Ensure the GPU is not overheating by monitoring temperatures.
Uninstall and reinstall the latest graphics driver.
Check if the graphics card is properly seated and functional.
problems.technical_details: Occurs due to graphics driver failures, overheating, or hardware malfunctions.

steps: Update SSD firmware from the manufacturer's website.
Update SATA controller drivers in Device Manager.
Run System File Checker (sfc /scannow) to check for corrupted files.
Uninstall any recently installed software that may be causing conflicts.
problems.technical_details: Often caused by outdated SSD firmware or incompatible drivers.

steps: Update all drivers in Device Manager.
Run System File Checker using command: sfc /scannow.
Check RAM using Windows Memory Diagnostic.
Boot into Safe Mode to troubleshoot faulty drivers.
problems.technical_details: Typically related to driver conflicts or corrupted system files.

steps: Check if the keyboard is properly connected (for wired keyboards).
Try using another USB port or reconnect the wireless receiver.
Restart the computer and check if the keyboard works.
Update or reinstall the keyboard drivers via Device Manager.
Test the keyboard on another device to check for hardware failure.
problems.technical_details: Keyboard issues can arise from loose connections, outdated drivers, or hardware failure.

steps: Check if the key is physically stuck or dirty; clean it gently.
Test the keyboard in another application or device.
Run the Windows Keyboard Troubleshooter in Settings > Update & Security > Troubleshoot.
Update keyboard drivers in Device Manager.
Use an external keyboard if the issue persists to check for hardware failure.
problems.technical_details: Keys may stop working due to dirt, driver issues, or physical damage.

steps: Check if the mouse is connected properly (for wired mice).
Try another USB port or change the batteries (for wireless mice).
Restart the computer and check if the mouse starts working.
Update or reinstall mouse drivers in Device Manager.
Test the mouse on another device to rule out hardware failure.
problems.technical_details: Mouse issues may be caused by loose connections, low battery, or driver corruption.

steps: Try using a different USB port or reconnect the wireless receiver.
Check if the mouse sensor is clean and free of dust.
Lower pointer speed in Settings > Devices > Mouse.
Update the mouse driver via Device Manager.
Disable pointer precision in Control Panel > Mouse Settings.
problems.technical_details: Lagging or freezing may occur due to interference, software settings, or driver issues.

steps: Press the touchpad enable/disable shortcut key (often Fn + F7 or similar).
Go to Settings > Devices > Touchpad and ensure it is enabled.
Update or reinstall the touchpad drivers in Device Manager.
Restart the laptop and check if the touchpad responds.
If using an external mouse, disconnect it and test the touchpad again.
problems.technical_details: The touchpad may be disabled in settings, blocked by an external mouse, or have driver-related issues.

steps: Shut down the device and let it cool for a few minutes before restarting.
Ensure the air vents are not blocked and clean them using compressed air.
Keep the device on a hard, flat surface instead of soft materials like beds or couches.
Close unused applications in Task Manager to reduce CPU load.
Check if the cooling fan is working properly; replace it if needed.
problems.technical_details: Overheating can be caused by blocked air vents, excessive CPU usage, or a failing cooling system.

problems.problem: Fan running loud or constantly at full speed
steps: Restart the device to see if the fan noise reduces.
Clean dust buildup inside the fan using compressed air.
Check for background applications consuming high CPU in Task Manager and close them.
Update BIOS and drivers to ensure fan control is optimized.
If the issue persists, consider replacing the cooling fan.
problems.technical_details: Fans run at high speeds when the system overheats, often due to dust buildup, high CPU usage, or outdated firmware.

problems.problem: Device shuts down due to overheating
steps: Let the device cool down before turning it on again.
Check if the cooling vents are clear and clean them if necessary.
Reduce multitasking by closing unnecessary programs.
Adjust power settings to 'Balanced' or 'Power Saver' mode to reduce heat.
Use a cooling pad or external fan to improve airflow.
problems.technical_details: Overheating shutdowns happen when the CPU or GPU reaches critical temperatures, triggering automatic protection.

problems.problem: Overheating while gaming or heavy tasks
steps: Lower in-game graphics settings to reduce GPU and CPU load.
Ensure the cooling fans are clean and functioning properly.
Keep the laptop or PC in a well-ventilated area to improve airflow.
Check for driver updates, especially GPU drivers.
Consider repasting thermal paste on the CPU/GPU if overheating persists.
problems.technical_details: Gaming and heavy tasks increase CPU/GPU load, leading to excess heat if cooling isn't sufficient.

steps: Remove the charger and let the laptop cool down.
Avoid using the device while charging for long periods.
Check battery health in 'Settings > Power & Battery'.
Replace an old or swollen battery immediately.
Use an original charger to prevent overheating issues.
problems.technical_details: Battery overheating can occur due to overcharging, old batteries, or using non-certified chargers.

steps: Check if the USB device works on another port or another computer.
Restart the computer and try the port again.
Update or reinstall USB drivers via Device Manager.
Disable USB Selective Suspend in Power Options.
Check for debris or physical damage inside the USB port.
problems.technical_details: USB ports may stop working due to driver issues, power settings, or physical damage.

steps: Ensure the HDMI cable is securely connected to both the device and the monitor/TV.
Try using a different HDMI cable or port.
Update graphics drivers in Device Manager.
Right-click on the desktop and select 'Display Settings' to detect the external display.
Restart the device with the HDMI cable connected.
problems.technical_details: HDMI issues may be caused by driver conflicts, faulty cables, or incorrect display settings.

steps: Check if the Ethernet cable is securely connected and not damaged.
Try using a different cable or connecting to a different router port.
Restart the router and computer.
Update network drivers via Device Manager.
Run network troubleshooting by going to Settings > Network & Internet > Troubleshoot.
problems.technical_details: Ethernet port issues may arise due to driver problems, cable faults, or network configuration errors.

steps: Check if the headphone or speaker works with another device.
Ensure the audio output device is set correctly in Sound Settings.
Update or reinstall audio drivers via Device Manager.
Clean the audio jack for dust or debris.
Try using an external USB audio adapter as a workaround.
problems.technical_details: Audio jacks may fail due to driver issues, incorrect settings, or hardware defects.

steps: Check if the charger and power outlet are functional by testing with another device.
Inspect the charging port for dust or debris and clean it carefully.
Try using a different charger or cable.
Restart the device and check if charging resumes.
If the issue persists, check for hardware failure or battery issues.
problems.technical_details: Charging ports can stop working due to power adapter failures, debris in the port, or hardware damage.

steps: Open Task Manager (Ctrl + Shift + Esc) and check which processes are using the most resources.
End unnecessary high-usage processes by right-clicking and selecting 'End Task'.
Disable unnecessary startup programs using Task Manager > Startup tab.
Run Windows Update to ensure system is up-to-date.
Check for malware using Windows Defender or another antivirus software.
problems.technical_details: High CPU and memory usage can slow down performance, often due to background processes, software conflicts, or malware.

steps: Disable unnecessary startup programs via Task Manager > Startup tab.
Perform a disk cleanup to remove temporary files using 'cleanmgr'.
Check for disk errors by running 'chkdsk /f /r' in Command Prompt.
Update drivers, especially graphics and chipset drivers.
Consider upgrading to an SSD for faster boot times.
problems.technical_details: Slow boot times may be caused by too many startup programs, hard drive issues, or outdated drivers.

steps: Ensure your system meets the software's minimum requirements.
Close unnecessary background applications.
Clear temporary files and cache from the system and browsers.
Update or reinstall problematic applications.
Run Windows Memory Diagnostic to check for RAM issues.
problems.technical_details: Software lag can be due to insufficient system resources, memory issues, or corrupted application files.

steps: Check available storage by opening 'This PC' and reviewing disk space.
Use 'Disk Cleanup' to remove temporary and system files.
Uninstall unused applications via Settings > Apps.
Move large files to an external drive or cloud storage.
Enable Storage Sense to automatically free up space.
problems.technical_details: Running low on storage can cause performance issues, especially if the system drive is nearly full.

steps: Open 'Device Manager' and check for drivers with warning symbols.
Update drivers using Windows Update or manufacturer's website.
Rollback recent driver updates if the issue started after an update.
Uninstall and reinstall problematic drivers.
Restart the system after updating drivers to apply changes.
problems.technical_details: Outdated or corrupt drivers can cause system slowdowns and application crashes.
